Today it has come to be regarded as one of the cultural treasures of China with major performance troupes based in Beijing, Tianjin and Shanghai.  4/4
 #beijingopera #springfestival

Since the orchestra played loudly, the performers developed a piercing style of song that could be heard by everyone. The costumes were a garish collection of sharply contrasting colors to stand out on the dimly illuminated stage. 3/4

Beijing Opera is a harmonious combination of ballet and acrobatics, consisting of dance, dialogue, monologues, martial arts and mime. In ancient times, it was performed mostly on stage in the open air, teahouses or temple courtyards. 2/4

Backstage Beijing opera: performers prepare for their grand entrance. During the just ended 15 day Chinese Lunar New Year or Spring Festival, opera performances have been taking place in makeshift theaters @ temples such as this one in a Beijing suburb. 1/4 #beijing #beijingopera https://t.co/Wl4vIoo3s5

After Topaz, my father never rode a horse again."

The author, Ken Yamashita was born in Topaz in 1945.

#topazbaby392 #japaneseamerican
#japaneseamericanhistory #stopasianhate

At age 39, he was undoubtedly one of the oldest cow"boys" amongst the riders at the Topaz cattle ranch. In 1951 he rejoined Mitsubishi and was charged with establishing its
New York headquarters as the new Mitsubishi International Corporation. 8/

My Cal Berkeley/Harvard Business School-alumnus, ex-businessman
father asked to be transferred to the agricultural division to work as a ranch hand. He achieved personal satisfaction from working outdoors as a Kibei cowboy, herding cattle astride his favorite horse, Red. 7/

This is why he was labeled as a
"Kibei" American born but educated in Japan. After working 14 months in Community Welfare, providing the camp's social services, my father was ready for a change. 6/

When my family was transported to the Topaz, Utah incarceration camp in September ‚Äò42, my father was assigned as the liaison to the Issei (1st gen) residents due to his Japanese-language proficiency which was gained from his 11y education in Tokyo (1911-1922). 5/

He was funneled from Berkeley to Tanforan detention center, a former race track in San Bruno, with my
mother Kiyoko Yamashita and my 18 month-old sister Kimiko.

My family was housed in a horse-stall "apartment" from May to September. 4/

"My father, Susumu Yamashita, was a junior executive at the San Francisco branch of Mitsubishi trading company before the December 7, 1941 Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor. On April 30, 1942, he was involved in the mass forced removal of the Japanese American community. 3/

I repost this picture of my Dad and accompanying story by my brother, Ken Yamashita, steming from this time of intense Asian hate. It offers a cautionary tale in light of the alarming spike in hate crimes against Asian Americans. 2/

LONG üßµ THE DAY OF REMEMBRANCE

2/19‚ÄìToday is the Day of
Remembrance marking the 80th anniversary of Executive Order 9066, when President Franklin Roosevelt launched the wrongful imprisonment of 120K people of Japanese ancestry during World War II, including my father (pictured). https://t.co/fRVzRCd8da

Chinese skiers now have over 800 ski resorts to choose from and Xinhua News reported that by January 2022, over 300 million Chinese participated in winter sports. 5/5
A major push by the Chinese government to increase participation in winter sports during the lead-up to the Olympics has triggered a wave of ski-fever. 4/5

-- making it one of Beijing's oldest and most historic, as it's located in Huairou district, which is surrounded by the Great Wall. As you can see here most of the crowd were newbies, who spent more time sliding down even the beginner slopes on their rears than on their skis. 3/5

I was at the Beijing Huaibei International Ski resort soon after its debut to photograph the introduction of what was then a new sport for China. The resort, located 70 km north of Beijing‚Äôs city center, opened in 2001 -- 2/5

Many were surprised when Beijing, not known for its ample snowfall, was named host of the 2022 Winter Olympics. China‚Äôs capital city typically sees just 6 days of snow per year due to its bone-dry winters. #huaibei #huairou #beijingski 1/5 https://t.co/zBYEmGsnkb
the Great Wall did little to stop the Mongols from threatening China. 3/3  #wildwall #Jinshanling

The hard part for visitors used to be climbing to the best locations for sunrise or sunset. Now a cable car stands ready to whisk you to the top. Though monumental in scale ‚Äî it‚Äôs the world‚Äôs largest man-made construction project 2/3

Wild Wall in winter: The Great Wall of China at Jinshanling, once known as the Wild Wall as it stood unrestored from the time it was rebuilt in the 16th century. Nothing wild about it now, as much of it has been completely repaired and surrounded by tourist shops. 1/3 #greatwall https://t.co/DdREO1iXB7

The vibrant yellows and reds of marigolds and mums are symbols of good luck and prosperity. The marigold, in particular, is a favorite for its connotations of longevity and good health. 2/2 #Vietnam #mekongdelta #tet

As essential to Tet as evergreens are to Christmas in the West, flowers are indispensable to new year celebrations. Flower villages prepare for the influx of buyers well before the beginning of Tet, and markets in the cities overflow with bouquets of marigolds. 1/2 https://t.co/kt3EF29P9D

Commonly hung in high places, Tibetans believe the prayers will be blown by the wind to spread good will, fortune and compassion to all, dispersing blessings to the heavens and to all beings in the world. Prayer flags are a common sight across Tibet. #tibet #prayerflags #nft 3/3
The colors represent the different elements: blue for sky, red for fire, green for water, yellow for earth, and white for air. 2/3

A hillside covered by thousands of Tibetan prayer flags in the colors of a rainbow. Prayer flags are rectangular or square pieces of cloth often with mantras printed on them. 1/3 https://t.co/860B0sggNr

that it even changed its name to Shangri-la to draw tourists searching for this enchanted place. #8daysoftibet #nftphotography #niftygateway #shangrila #sumzanlin #shambala 5/5
Zhongdian, a town in northwest Yunnan Province, China so closely resembles such a place -- complete with lamasery, ancient pagodas and serene lakes surrounded by snow-capped mountains -- 4/5

The book and subsequent movies based on it have captivated the public imagination ever since. Writers and explorers have all attempted to identify the actual spot that gave rise to Hilton's mythical valley in the foothills of the Himalayas. 3/5

It is thought to have inspired the mythical Shangri-La of the 1933 novel, Lost Horizon, by British author James Hilton. Hilton likely took the name Shangri-la from the Tibetan Buddhist term ‚ÄúShambala‚Äù, which refers to a hidden earthly paradise.2/5
